October 2017
Communication skills need to stronger , send up to date documents to the guest so that everyone is on the same page, improve customer service overall
Response from Izabel:
Lorraine came with her friend. We had some issues with their check in. She informed us that they want to drop off their bags at 7am to which we agreed, normal check in was 4-7pm. They were taking the bus from Montreal to NY. They also asked that they want to 'freshen up' after the long trip - we said that if the bathroom is available, they can but not for long because current guests have priority to use the bathroom. She texted us through the night 2am and 6am, informing us that they will be late. 7am, no update even after we texted them. Then they just showed up around 830am and told us that we did not respond, apparently expecting us to reply in the middle of the night. We texted them around 7am to which they did not reply even though they said they will inform us when they reach the bus station. The bathroom was occupied when they arrived as normal in the morning and we told them they had to wait. We had to tell them to limit their time in the bathroom to maximum 5 minutes as they wanted to use it for longer. It seemed that they were not appreciative that we accommodated their early arrival nor were they considerate of our current guests. We gave them the key to the front door so they can come back later to check in, they said 4 pm. But they showed up at 2pm without notifying us. It would have been common courtesy to do so. As it happened, we were home and the room was ready so they were able to check in their room 2 hours early. We feel these guests are inconsiderate and that they are entitled to their own wants without respect of house rules and other guests.
October 2017

We stayed at Clifford's place for 10 days. The room was sunny and spacious, which was nice. Some things in the apartment might have been cleaner: some dishes were not washed properly, so we needed to wash them again before eating; when we arrived, there was a some hair (and dust)…Read more
Response from Clifford:
I'm sorry to hear that there were some issues with your stay. Thank you for the feedback, as I'm always striving to be better. A few things to note: Usually I make sure to clean the bathroom regularly, but I had just returned from a business trip when Anastasia arrived (and there had been a previous guest staying), so I wasn't able to clean the bathroom until the next day. I will do better with that in the future. As far as street noise, I had recently installed the window air conditioner which does let in some additional noise (the window AC is not installed in the winter). That said, there have been several guests after Anastasia who have said the room is very quiet, so I suppose it just depends on perspective. In my experience living in a number of NYC apartments, it is much quieter than most, even with the AC in. Also, I believe the noise level could have had something to do with the window AC not being turned on because we ended up having cooler weather during Anastasia's stay. When the AC is on, noise from outside harder to hear. As far as communication goes, unfortunately due to how much I work, I sometimes have more or less time to show guests around. I have a thorough email that all guest receive before their arrival. I also want to note that there is a guide book in the bedroom that I have prepared with a lot of information about the apartment and the neighborhood. Towels are in the hallway closet (there is a sign on the closet door).

Response from Zen Home:
Hi Leonard, As clearly stated in our policy, we don't allow any type of parties to be allowed at our place. The place has strict occupancy guideline of 3 people as mentioned in Airbnb and the place was booked for only two people. The number of guests present in the apartment was definitely way more than 3 people and there was a house party going in the apartment. We rent our places strictly for residential purposes and these can't be used as party pad by guests. We apologize for the experience, but we received numerous complaints from building management regarding noise. We were left with no choice but to obtain copies of everyone visiting the apartment, without any knowledge to us. Please understand that this is residential building, where people stay with their kids and we are required to take steps to ensure safety of residents of the building. Again, we don't rent our properties for parties - house parties, extra number of guests, smoking in the apartment is strictly prohibited. It is very very clearly listed on our listings.

Case in point: the door was newly broken, Patricia failed to mention it to me until the review over a week later. I fixed it immediately bc that IS something that actually matters! FUTURE RENTERS - the "mattress on the floor" is the highest quality natural latex mattress set atop a platform that was designed specifically for that purpose - it is not a "floor" designed for any other use than sleeping. My cleaning gal did a full sweep of all the cabinets to check for opening and pest homes. She found nothing, which is on par with my experience for the last 5 years. Response from Jenny:
Guest, Zoulikha initially booked for 5 days and then she extended the same apartment twice for 8 days each. If she have had so many issues with apartment then she must not have booked. We believe her whole review is about luggage pickup. SHE did come to our office and met, same Indian guy. She was supposed to leave on Jan 20, and she did leave on Jan 20. We have had very clear instructions to leave the keys in the apartment. Instead she took one key to front desk at 10pm and asked front desk to keep the key. Front desk has very strict policy not to handle any keys at all. Front desk work for building management and not our company. But she started creating a scene with front desk person, and he was new. He got scared and kept one key. Now, at 11pm she calls our company phone ( BTW, the Indian guy with heavy accent is my husband) and my husband answers and she tells that she left for the airport. She left one key with front desk. Front desk agreed to help her company give the luggage to them.(front desk shift changes at 11pm and the same guy is not scheduled to work for another 48 hours). Yes, she did leave the apartment and country and left her luggage in our apartment. We never agreed to keep her luggage. If you are going to make such arrangements, guests first speak to us then we all agree on the process. But in this case, she sigle handedly decided on whole process and confirmed to herself that 1) . It is ok leave the luggage in the apartment beyond her checkout date, 2) it is ok not to take permission from our office whether it is ok or not. 3) assumed that front desk will be OK to keep the keys. (she decided to walk to front desk guy at time of check out and forced keys on him). Our company can't handle such arrangements. OK, then next day she was not reachable on cell, she called back after 72 hours and she become abusive that why can't we keep the luggage. Our next guest refused to checkin to the apartment because she left almost six bags including open boxes in plastic move in boxes. Airbnb was not able to reach her either. About us : I started with one furnished apartment few years back, we expanded our operations and my husband joined. We hired couple of people to help us and provide excellent customer service. It is not practical feasible for me to be there all the time and provide service. At this time, we host close to 4000 reservations in one year.Our office is always staffed from 9am to 8pm, just to provide on-site customer service. Guest could store their luggage free of cost in our office located in same building. We request you to please give us heads up and don't leave anything in apartment. We have guests who have stored their luggage for fees in our storage while they make trip to other parts of USA. But they have all been very nice to move their luggage into our office and they never left it in the apartment. Building maintenance do enter apartments to schedule regular maintenance. You can check all the reviews and there was never an incident where something happened. Also, our office ask every guest whether it is ok to enter the apartment in their absence. ******We request everyone to please read at other old and recent reviews. *********

Beware of this listing. Very disappointing Airbnb experience. My boyfriend and I decided to stay at this apartment for 2 nights, after we saw the positive reviews and pictures. In reality, the level of cleanliness wasn't as the pictures make it seem. We arrived at the apartment…Read more
Response from BrooklynSleeps:
We are absolutely shocked at this feedback... we've hosted dozens of guests and have been rated an average of 4.5 stars, which is no trivial achievement. I would encourage visitors to read through our other reviews to get a more realistic perspective, and we are including our review of Emma below: Emma was quite polite in general, and our overall experience hosting Emma and her boyfriend was okay... but we kind of felt like the help rather than their hosts. Upon arrival, there was some unhappiness about a bit of lint on the bedsheets. We were very sorry about the sheets and remade the bed straight away. And then we heard that Emma saw some hairs in the bathroom, but only after both Emma and her boyfriend had freshened up and showered. We often board dogs at our apartment, and despite our best scrub sessions in the bathroom sometimes hairs find their way back into the guest bathroom. In the end, it didn't matter—we cleaned the bathroom a second time without question. On a different night of their stay, we were finishing up a movie when we heard Emma and her boyfriend come in for the night. We saw that they were beginning to prepare for sleep, so we made sure the volume was at a very modest level. Even still, Emma complained that the sound was too loud. We of course reduced the volume more, even if it meant that subtitles were necessary. All in all, we think perhaps Emma was expecting more of a hotel experience, or even to have a space not shared by the hosts.
September 2015

Thanks for the feedback! I want to sincerely apologize you got a parking ticket. We never have issues finding street parking out front of the building though. The neighborhood is perfectly safe. It is definitely cultural diverse, but mostly consists of families and young professionals. We've been living in the area for years and never had any issues whatsoever. We stayed at Clifford's place for 10 days. The room was sunny and spacious, which was nice. Some things in the apartment might have been cleaner: some dishes were not washed properly, so we needed to wash them again before eating; when we arrived, there was a some hair (and dust)…Read more
Response from Clifford:
I'm sorry to hear that there were some issues with your stay. Thank you for the feedback, as I'm always striving to be better. A few things to note: Usually I make sure to clean the bathroom regularly, but I had just returned from a business trip when Anastasia arrived (and there had been a previous guest staying), so I wasn't able to clean the bathroom until the next day. I will do better with that in the future. As far as street noise, I had recently installed the window air conditioner which does let in some additional noise (the window AC is not installed in the winter). That said, there have been several guests after Anastasia who have said the room is very quiet, so I suppose it just depends on perspective. In my experience living in a number of NYC apartments, it is much quieter than most, even with the AC in. Also, I believe the noise level could have had something to do with the window AC not being turned on because we ended up having cooler weather during Anastasia's stay. When the AC is on, noise from outside harder to hear. As far as communication goes, unfortunately due to how much I work, I sometimes have more or less time to show guests around. I have a thorough email that all guest receive before their arrival. I also want to note that there is a guide book in the bedroom that I have prepared with a lot of information about the apartment and the neighborhood. Towels are in the hallway closet (there is a sign on the closet door).
